comment._content: While I thought the whole series was fascinating, I wished for accompanying text to explain what they were doing and why they wre doing it. Today, in Yahoo News, I found a story that says they found that the Lady Hor is actually male.... news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090624/ap_on_fe_st/us_odd_mummies_s...

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Hi Susan63117 - I agree, we were actually live tweeting the story and then linking to all the photos as we went along. So the story is actually on Twitter. We have some information on that in the set description including how to search our hashtag, but depending on how you arrived at the photos, I can see how it would be confusing! Maybe next time we will just use something like twitpic to accompany photos to tweets, rather than trying to cross-platform the whole event. That might work a little better. Thanks for the helpful feedback! ~Shelley Edit: For now, I've batch appended the caption from the set to all the photos, which should help a little. Wish I had time to do that yesterday, but it was pretty hectic...anyway...thanks for the comment - this should make it a little clearer.

comment.author: 21236485@N04
comment._content:
I wondered if the reed was actually a feather.  The feather is associated with "Truth" and at death each king proclaimed that he was mAa xrw, or "True of Voice" meaning that he had not lied.  It is part of what is known as the Negative Confession.  Also, during his judgement in the afterlife his heart is weighed against this feather of truth.

Though I have never heard of a feather being physically inserted to the throat of a mummy it would seem to make more sense in this context than a reed.  But this is all just speculation.
